questions.question:
Question 1: A newborn baby has a characteristic rash as shown below. On examination, bilateral pearly 
white nuclear cataracts are noted, and a continuous murmur is auscultated. What family does 
the virus implicated in this syndrome belong to?
questions.explanation:
The clinical scenario of bilateral nuclear cataracts, blueberry muffin rash (image), and patent 
ductus arteriosus(murmur) suggest congenital rubella syndrome. Rubella virus belongs to the 
family Matonaviridae. Rubella virus previously belonged to family Togaviridae, but has been recently changed to family 
Matonaviridae by the International Committee on the Taxonomy of viruses (ICTV), making it the 
sole genus under the family Matonaviridae. Option A: Rhabdoviridae includes Rabies virus. 438 
Sold by @itachibot Option B: Filoviridae includes Marburg virus and Ebola virus. Option D: Calciviridae includes Norwalk agent.

questions.question:
Question 2: A brain biopsy done at the time of autopsy shows spongiform encephalopathy. Which of the 
following is unlikely to be the diagnosis? 432 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
Spongiform encephalopathy is a feature of prion disease. Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis 
(SSPE) is not a prion disease. SSPE is a rare and chronic form of progressive brain inflammation caused by a persistent 
infection with the measles virus. Slow virus diseases are characterized by a long asymptomatic period, often months or years in 
duration, between the introduction of the infectious agent and the appearance of clinical illness. 
Examples: AIDS, Kuru, CJD, SSPE, PML CJD, Kuru, and mad cow disease are classified under slow virus diseases which are caused by 
prions.

questions.question: Question 3: Which strain of the Ebola virus has the highest case fatality rate?
questions.explanation:
The Zaire strain has a case fatality rate of 90% There are five identified Ebola virus strains, four of which are known to cause disease in humans: • Ebola virus (Zaire ebolavirus) • Sudan virus (Sudan ebolavirus) • Taï Forest virus (Taï Forest ebolavirus) • Bundibugyo virus (Bundibugyo ebolavirus). 439 
Sold by @itachibot The fifth, Reston virus (Reston ebolavirus), has caused disease in nonhuman primates, but not in 
humans. The Bundibugyo ebolavirus, Zaire ebolavirus, and Sudan ebolavirus have been associated with 
large outbreaks in Africa. The strain that caused the 2014–2016 West African outbreak belongs to 
the Zaire ebolavirus species.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following is a leading cause of diarrheal death in children?
questions.explanation:
Rotavirus is a leading cause of diarrheal death among children in the developing world. Rotavirus infections occur in most children below the age of 5 years and are most frequent 
between 6-24 months of age. Neonatal infections are common but are often asymptomatic or 
mild. Vaccines for rotavirus: RotaTeq and Rotarix, given orally. Note: Viruses that can cause diarrhoea in children include: • Rotavirus (most common) • Norwalk virus • Adenovirus- types 40 and 41 • Astrovirus • Coronavirus • Sapovirus The image below shows an electron micrograph image of the Rotavirus.

questions.question:
Question 5: An 18-year-old went on an exchange program to Singapore. An adventurous eater, she tried 
clams and oysters on a cruise ship. 2 days later, she developed fever, nausea, vomiting, and 
diarrhea. What is the causative agent?
questions.explanation:
440 
Sold by @itachibot The clinical scenario describes a case of Norwalk infection. It is the most common cause of 
diarrhea in older children and adults. They occur in group settings such as banquet halls, cruise ships, dormitories, and campgrounds, 
where outbreak sources are usually contaminated food and/or water. Potential sources of 
contaminated food include shellfish such as clams and oysters, which are contaminated by water. Clinical features are nausea, vomiting, watery diarrhea, abdominal pain. Symptoms of 
gastroenteritis develop 12 to 48 hours after being exposed to norovirus. The image below is an electron micrograph of Norovirus (Norwalk virus).

questions.question:
Question 6: A 70-year-old lady with recent onset, progressive dementia comes with myoclonus. The brain 
imaging is shown below. What biochemical component is responsible for this disease?
questions.explanation:
The clinical features and imaging suggest a diagnosis of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease(CJD), caused 
by prions. Prions are composed of protein. These are infectious protein particles that lack any nucleic acid. They are filterable like viruses but 
are resistant to agents of sterilization. Prion proteins have two isoforms: • PrPSc is the prion protein that causes disease. • PrPc is the normal prion protein, found in human cells. Prions cause diseases such as CJD, Kuru, Alzheimer's, Parkinson's. Laboratory diagnosis of prion diseases: • Measurement of PrPSc by immunoassay • Brain MRI • Brain biopsy • Stress protein 14-3-3 441 
Sold by @itachibot • Sequencing PRNP gene • Abnormal EEG

questions.question:
Question 7: A 32-year-old lady is admitted to the ICU with COVID-19. Which of the following statements 
is false regarding the organism causing it? 434 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: These viruses have club-shaped peplomers on their surface
options.d: It acts by binding to ACE1 and TMPRSS4 receptors

questions.explanation:
The coronavirus spike protein binds to the ACE2 and TMPRSS2 receptors to enter the human 
cells. Coronaviruses are a group of spherical or pleomorphic enveloped RNA viruses having club or 
petal-shaped peplomers. Coronaviruses are named for the crown-like spikes on their surface. It spreads through coughing, sneezing, and close personal contact such as touching the mouth, 
nose. The virus is highly mutable and so vaccine prophylaxis for all strains is difficult. Coronaviruses cause upper respiratory tract infections, severe acute respiratory syndrome (SARS), 
and Middle Eastern respiratory syndrome (MERS). They spread by inhalation of the virus present 
in droplets or aerosols of respiratory secretions of the patients. Basic protective measures against the new coronavirus: (SARS-CoV-2) • Wash your hands frequently for at least 20 seconds. • Maintain social distancing- Maintain at least 1 meter distance between yourself and anyone who 
is coughing or sneezing • Avoid touching eyes, nose, and mouth • Practice respiratory hygiene- cover your mouth and nose with your bent elbow or tissue when 
you cough or sneeze, then dispose of the used tissue immediately. • If you have fever, cough, and difficulty breathing, seek medical care early • Stay informed and follow the advice given by your healthcare provider 442 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 8: A person who comes in contact with a case of coronavirus (COVID- 19) needs to be followed 
up for  
.
questions.explanation:
A person who comes in contact with a coronavirus(COVID-19) case (confirmed or probable) needs 
to be followed up for apperance of symptoms of coronavirus for the maximum incubation period 
of 14 days. Treatment: There is no specific antiviral treatment recommended for COVID-19. People with 
COVID-19 should receive supportive care to help relieve symptoms. For severe cases, treatment 
should include care to support vital organ functions. Basic protective measures against the new coronavirus: (SARS CoV 2) • Wash your hands frequently for atleast 20 seconds. • Maintain social distancing- Maintain at least 1 metre distance between yourself and anyone who 
is coughing or sneezing • Avoid touching eyes, nose and mouth • Practice respiratory hygiene- cover your mouth and nose with your bent elbow or tissue when 
you cough or sneeze, then dispose of the used tissue immediately. • If you have fever, cough and difficulty breathing, seek medical care early • Stay informed and follow advice given by your healthcare provider

questions.question:
Question 9: In a patient undergoing testing for SARS-CoV, a FELUDA test is done. Which of the following 
statements is false about this technology?

options.a: It is the acronym for FNCAS9 Editor Linked Uniform Detection Assay
options.b: Based on CRISPR gene editing technology
options.c: It is slower than RT PCR in detecting SARS-CoV2
options.d: It uses CAS-9 protein to bind to the viral signature

questions.explanation:
FELUDA is faster than RT-PCR in detecting SARS-CoV2. FELUDA (FNCAS9 Editor Linked Uniform Detection Assay) is a newly approved method based on 
CRISPR gene-editing technology to identify and target the genetic material of SARS-CoV2. The CRISPR technology uses a highly specific CAS9 protein to find and bind to the target Covid 
signature. This is then coupled with paper-strip chemistry to elicit a visual readout on a paper 
strip. It is a very affordable, sensitive (96%), and specific (98%) strip test which can detect viral genetic 
material within 45 minutes.

questions.question: Question 10: A confirmed case of which of the following viral haemorrhagic fevers was found in India?
questions.explanation:
Crimean Congo hemorrhagic fever is a severe form of viral hemorrhagic fever, is caused by 
Nairovirus species. It is zoonotic in origin with ticks as vectors. The outbreak was caused due to person-to-person 
transmission in hospitals. 443 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: 435 
Sold by @itachibot A woman presents with a positive urine pregnancy test, 1 month after taking the MMR 
vaccine. At the time of receiving the vaccine, she had been advised to avoid conception. What 
advice do you give her now?

options.c: Low risk; termination of pregnancy may be considered
options.d: High risk of anomalies; serious consideration for termination

questions.explanation:
In this case scenario, the doctor should advise the patient to wait and watch. The vaccine should not be administered during pregnancy. If pregnancy occurs within 28 days of 
immunization, the patient should be counseled on the theoretical risks for the fetus. Studies of over 200 women who had been inadvertently immunized with rubella vaccine during 
pregnancy showed that none of their offspring developed congenital rubella syndrome. Therefore, 
termination of pregnancy is probably not warranted.

questions.question:
Question 12: While working at a WHO outreach post in Africa, you conduct an educational program about 
the Zika virus. What family does this virus belong to?
questions.explanation:
Zika virus belongs to the family Flaviviridae. It is classified by the International Committee on Taxonomy of Viruses (ICTV): • Family: Flaviviridae • Genus: Flavivirus • Species: Zika virus Zika virus is an RNA virus that is transmitted by Aedes aegypti mosquito bite and by sexual 
contact. It causes microcephaly and is associated with Guillain-Barré syndrome.

questions.question: Question 13: Zika virus is transmitted by:
questions.explanation:
Zika virus may be transmitted by the bite of infected Aedes aegypti and Aedes albopictus. The symptoms of Zika virus disease include fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, 
malaise, or headache. These symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days. Zika virus infection during pregnancy may cause lead to microcephaly or congenital Zika 
syndrome. The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and 
myelitis.

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following features do not support a diagnosis of Zika fever?
questions.explanation:
A petechial rash is not a primary feature of Zika virus infection. Though petechiae may rarely appear in Zika virus disease it is however not included in the CDC 
case definition of Zika virus disease. Petechial rash points towards a diagnosis of dengue fever 
while a maculopapular rash suggests a Zika virus disease. Zika virus infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache, and 
malaise. A maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and arthralgia usually accompany or 
follow those manifestations. 444 
Sold by @itachibot The complications of Zika virus are: • Guillain-Barre syndrome • Fetal microcephaly in pregnant women.

questions.question:
Question 15: The transplacental transmission of the organism given in the image which causes 
microcephaly is-
questions.explanation:
The transplacental transmission of Zika virus given in the image causes microcephaly. The condition shown in the image is microcephaly. It is caused by Zika virus transmission from an 
infected pregnant mother to her child. Zika virus is a mosquito-borne Flavivirus mainly 
transmitted through Aedes aegypti. Symptoms are mild and usually last for 2-7 days. • Fever • Rash • Conjunctivitis • Muscle and joint pain • Malaise • Headache • In pregnancy- congenital Zika syndrome or microcephaly The complications of Zika virus infection include Guillain-Barré syndrome, neuropathy, and 
myelitis. NCDC Delhi and the National Institute of Virology Pune, are the only institutes that have the 
capacity to provide the diagnosis in an acute febrile stage. RT-PCR is the standard test available 
for the diagnosis of Zika virus infection.

questions.question: Question 16: Tropical spastic paraparesis is caused by:
questions.explanation:
is the causative agent of the neurodegenerative disorder HTLV-1-associated myelopathy or 
tropical spastic paraparesis (HAM/TSP). The condition resembles multiple sclerosis and is associated with progressive weakness of legs 
and lower body. The patients develop spastic paraparesis or paraplegia, hyperreflexia, ankle 
clonus, and extensor plantar response. The disease progresses slowly and takes the form of 
thoracic myelopathy. Other conditions caused by HTLV-1 include: • Adult T-cell leukemias and lymphomas (ATL) • Uveitis • Infective dermatitis 445 
Sold by @itachibot • Arthritis • Sjo■gren’s syndrome

questions.question: Question 17: What family does the Nipah virus belong to?
questions.explanation:
Nipah virus belongs to the family Paramyxoviridae. Togaviridae contains chikungunya virus. Flaviviridae contains yellow fever virus, dengue virus, Japanese encephalitis virus, hepatitis C 
virus, Zika virus Bunyaviridae contains sandfly fever virus, hantaviruses. 446 
Sold by @itachibot Superficial and Systemic Mycoses
